subhed: War in Sudan: A Trapped Nation (2/6). After serving as the civil war's frontline for two years, Khartoum was retaken by the official army in March. Since then, the city has been struggling to rise from its ashes.

title: 'The Democratic Party waits for Trump's departure, hoping his successors fail to revive Trumpism'
subhed: In the face of Trump and his triumphant ethnonationalism, the regulatory parties – whether it be on artificial intelligence, environmental policy, financial capitalism or international relations – are remaining silent for now, notes Le Monde editorial writer Gilles Paris.

title: In China, a Ming dynasty painting donated to a major museum resurfaces at auction
subhed: A masterpiece from the Nanjing Museum, donated by the family of a renowned collector, recently appeared at an auction, reigniting debate over the management of public collections.

title: Dry January's lasting benefits win over more and more participants
subhed: The challenge, which involves taking a break from drinking alcohol for one month, brings numerous health benefits. As proof of its success, alcohol-free initiatives are gaining ground.

title: Kharkiv ends the year amid bombs and Christmas lights
subhed: Despite the ever-present sound of air-raid sirens, the city in eastern Ukraine decided to deck itself out in Christmas colors to recapture some festive spirit. Yet the semblance of normalcy remains difficult for some residents to fully embrace.

Iran's protests led by shopkeepers is shaking up the regime
byline: By Claire Gatinois and Ghazal Golshiri
subhed: The collapse of the rial currency deepens the economic struggles faced by retailers, who have taken to the streets in several major cities. Some universities in Tehran have also joined the mobilization, as economic grievances merge with increasingly political slogans.

title: New Year's Eve 2015 in Cologne: The night that traumatized thousands of women and shook Germany
subhed: On New Year's Eve in 2015, more than 1,000 women were sexually assaulted in Cologne by groups of men, many from North Africa and the Middle East, triggering a fierce debate over Germany's refugee policy. Ten years on, victims say their trauma was politicized, as they continue to live with the consequences of that night.

title: 'In the beginning, I was very diligent, more than other believers from Muslim backgrounds': Grégory's conversion to Islam
subhed: 'Changing Faith' (3/11). Why do people choose a particular religion? Attracted from a young age to Islam, Grégory Gonty, a 35-year-old Belgian social worker, became Muslim at the age of 21. The fervent believer has since become a knowledgeable and inquisitive practitioner.
